title: Ho un caso di separazione giudiziale in cui la moglie chiede un assegno di mante

history.content: Ho un caso di separazione giudiziale in cui la moglie chiede un assegno di mantenimento di 1.500 euro al mese\\ndopo un matrimonio durato 20 anni.\\nNon ci sono figli, ma la moglie non lavora da molti anni e il marito ha un reddito elevato.\\nVorrei capire quali criteri usa il giudice per riconoscere l’assegno e determinarne l’importo\\ne se esistono orientamenti giurisprudenziali o casi simili che possano orientare la valutazione.

In un caso di separazione giudiziale in Italia, il giudice considera diversi criteri per determinare l'assegno di mantenimento, specialmente in situazioni come quella descritta, in cui la moglie non lavora e il marito ha un reddito elevato. I principali criteri includono:

1. **Bisogni economici del richiedente**: Il giudice valuta le necessità economiche della moglie, tenendo conto della sua situazione finanziaria e della sua capacità di lavorare.

2. **Reddito del coniuge obbligato**: Il reddito del marito è un fattore cruciale. Un reddito elevato può giustificare un assegno di mantenimento più alto.

3. **Durata del matrimonio**: Un matrimonio lungo, come nel vostro caso di 20 anni, può influenzare positivamente la richiesta di mantenimento, poiché si presume che il coniuge richiedente possa aver sacrificato opportunità lavorative per la famiglia.

4. **Stile di vita durante il matrimonio**: Il giudice considera anche lo stile di vita mantenuto durante il matrimonio e se il coniuge richiedente ha diritto a mantenere un tenore di vita simile.

5. **Orientamenti giurisprudenziali**: Ci sono precedenti giuridici che possono influenzare la decisione, come casi in cui il mantenimento è stato concesso a coniugi non lavoratori dopo lunghi matrimoni, specialmente in assenza di figli.

In sintesi, il giudice utilizzerà una combinazione di questi fattori per decidere se concedere l'assegno e in quale misura. È consigliabile consultare un avvocato specializzato in diritto di famiglia per una valutazione più dettagliata e personalizzata del caso.

ARTICLE 166-BIS
PROHIBITION OF THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A DOWRY
Any agreement that in any way aims at the establishment of assets as a dowry is null and void.

ARTICLE 193 
JUDICIAL SEPARATION OF ASSETS
Judicial separation of property may be pronounced in the event of interdiction or incapacitation of one of the spouses or maladministration of the community.
It may also be pronounced when the disorder of the affairs of one of the spouses or the conduct of one of the spouses in the administration of property endangers the interests of the other or of the community or the family, or when one of the spouses does not contribute to the latter's needs in proportion to his or her substance and capacity for work.
Separation may be requested by one of the spouses or his or her legal representative.
The judgment pronouncing the separation run from the day on which the application was made and shall have the effect of establishing the separation of property regime regulated in Section V of this Chapter, without prejudice to the rights of third parties.
The judgment is noted in the margin of the marriage certificate and on the original of the marriage agreements.

ARTICLE 180 
ADMINISTRATION OF COMMUNITY PROPERTY
The administration of the community property and the representation in court for acts relating thereto belong separately to both spouses.
The performance of acts beyond ordinary administration, as well as the conclusion of contracts granting or acquiring personal rights of enjoyment and the representation in court for related actions are jointly entitled to both spouses.

history.content: can you help me with divorce cases in italy? how jurisdiction works? give me some past legal cases

In Italy, divorce cases are governed by specific legal provisions that outline the jurisdiction and procedures involved. The jurisdiction for divorce typically falls under the family courts, which handle matters related to marriage, separation, and divorce.

### Jurisdiction
1. **Where to File**: A divorce petition can be filed in the court of the place where the spouses have their habitual residence or where the marriage was celebrated.
2. **Types of Divorce**: There are two main types of divorce in Italy:
   - **Divorce by mutual consent**: Both spouses agree to the divorce and its terms.
   - **Judicial divorce**: One spouse files for divorce without the other's consent, which may involve a court hearing.

### Legal Framework
- **Dissolution of Communion**: According to Article 191, the community of property between spouses is dissolved upon legal separation or divorce.
- **Judicial Separation of Assets**: Article 193 allows for judicial separation of property in cases of incapacity, maladministration, or when one spouse fails to contribute to the family's needs.

### Past Legal Cases
While specific past legal cases are not provided in the context, notable cases in Italian divorce law often involve disputes over property division, child custody, and alimony. Courts typically consider the welfare of children and the contributions of each spouse to the marriage when making decisions.

For detailed legal advice or representation, it is advisable to consult a lawyer specializing in family law in Italy.

ARTICLE 191 
DISSOLUTION OF COMMUNION
Communion is dissolved by declaration of absence or presumed death of one of the spouses, annulment, dissolution or termination of the civil effects of the marriage, legal separation, judicial separation of property, conventional change of property regime, bankruptcy of one of the spouses.
In the case of legal separation, the community of property between the spouses is dissolved at the time when the president of the court authorises the spouses to live separately, or on the date of the signing of the minutes of the consensual separation of the spouses before the president, provided that they have been approved. The order by which the spouses are authorised to live separately is communicated to the civil registrar for the purposes of recording the dissolution of the community of property.
In the case of companies managed by both spouses and established after the marriage (art 177 lett. d), the dissolution of community may be decided by agreement of the spouses, observing the form provided for in Article 162, or by public deed or by declaration in the marriage certificate.

ARTICLE 193 
JUDICIAL SEPARATION OF ASSETS
Judicial separation of property may be pronounced in the event of interdiction or incapacitation of one of the spouses or maladministration of the community.
It may also be pronounced when the disorder of the affairs of one of the spouses or the conduct of one of the spouses in the administration of property endangers the interests of the other or of the community or the family, or when one of the spouses does not contribute to the latter's needs in proportion to his or her substance and capacity for work.
Separation may be requested by one of the spouses or his or her legal representative.
The judgment pronouncing the separation run from the day on which the application was made and shall have the effect of establishing the separation of property regime regulated in Section V of this Chapter, without prejudice to the rights of third parties.
The judgment is noted in the margin of the marriage certificate and on the original of the marriage agreements.

ARTICLE 159 
STATUTORY MATRIMONIAL PROPERTY REGIME
The statutory matrimonial property regime (in the absence of a different agreement concluded pursuant to Article 162, according to which marital agreements must be concluded by authentic instrument under penalty of nullity, the choice of the separation regime may also be declared in the marriage ceremony, the agreements may be concluded at any time) shall be community of property governed by artt. 177 ff.
